Authors: Comini, G.; Cortella, G.; Manzán, M.
Author full names: Comini, Gianni (7005313868); Cortella, Giovanni (6602167196); Manzán, Marco (6601986944)
Title: A streamfunction-vorticity-based finite-element formulation for laminar-convection problems
Source title: Numerical Heat Transfer, Part B: Fundamentals
Affiliations: Istituto di Fisica Tecnica e di Tecnologie Industriali, Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Comini, Gianni, Istituto di Fisica Tecnica e di Tecnologie Industriali, Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy; Cortella, Giovanni, Istituto di Fisica Tecnica e di Tecnologie Industriali, Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy; Manzán, Marco, Istituto di Fisica Tecnica e di Tecnologie Industriali, Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy
Abstract: The finite-element method is used to solve mixed-, farced-, and natural-convection problems in two-dimensional incompressible laminar flows. The streamfunction-vorticity equations are uncoupled and solved in sequence with the energy equation. The wall vorticity is evaluated in the framework of the streamfunction equation, and particular care is taken to specify inflow and outflow boundary conditions properly. The resulting scheme achieves convergence without the traditional need for upwinding, even for very high values of the Reynolds and the Rayleigh numbers. Stability and accuracy of the approach are demonstrated by the solution of three well-known test problems concerning mixed and forced convection downstream of a backward-facing step, and natural convection in a heated square cavity. © 1995 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Index Keywords: Boundary conditions; Finite element method; Laminar flow; Numerical analysis; Two phase flow; Wall flow; Laminar-convection problem; Streamfunction; Natural convection
Abbreviated Source Title: Numer Heat Transfer Part B Fundam

Authors: Crosilla, F.; Pillirone, G.
Author full names: Crosilla, Fabio (6602452091); Pillirone, G. (6505582619)
Title: Testing the data quality of a GIS database by bootstrap methods and other nonparametric statistics
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Crosilla, Fabio, Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy; Pillirone, G., Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy
Abstract: This paper describes a procedure, based on non-parametric statistics, for testing the data quality of a G.I.S. The procedure compares the contents of a database with a sample of control values captured on field and tests the hypothesis of no difference between the two samples, by the application of the Wilcoxon rank-sum test. The alternative hypothesis of the test is explicitly considered in order to evaluate the power function and the sensitivity of the test. Power formulas for the Wilcoxon test require some quantities to be estimated, and this is done by bootstrap techniques. The main advantage of the proposed procedure is the optimization of the number of control points required, since the sample size needed for the achievement of a certain sensitivity level is computed with the power function.
Index Keywords: Control systems; Data processing; Estimation; Optimization; Quality control; Testing; Bootstrap methods; Dataquality; Geographic information systems; Database systems
Editors: Ebner, Heinrich; Heipke, Christian; Eder, Konrad
Abbreviated Source Title: Proc SPIE Int Soc Opt Eng

Authors: Giovagnoni, M.
Author full names: Giovagnoni, Marco (6701835408)
Title: A numerical and experimental analysis of a chain of flexible bodies
Source title: Journal of Dynamic Systems, Measurement and Control
Affiliations: Istituto di Meccanica Teorica ed Applicata, Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Giovagnoni, Marco, Istituto di Meccanica Teorica ed Applicata, Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy
Abstract: A flexible multi-body dynamics approach is described. It uses an equivalent rigid link system from which are measured small displacements. The equations of motion are obtained by direct application of the principle of virtual work. Some terms in the virtual and real components have been neglected by virtue of the small displacement assumption. The use of sensitivity coefficients allows one to obtain a formulation which can be easily interfaced with any kinematic solution algorithm. It also enables one to check the correctness of the chosen equivalent rigid link system. The theory is then employed to reproduce numerically the experimental recordings obtained from a flexible linkage. Agreement between experimental and numerical data is good. © 1994 by ASME.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Dynamics; Equations of motion; Experiments; Kinematics; Mathematical models; Numerical analysis; Sensitivity analysis; Systems analysis; Equivalent rigid link system; Flexible bodies; Kinematic solution algorithms; Multibody dynamics; Sensitivity coefficients; Flexible structures
Abbreviated Source Title: J Dyn Syst Meas Control Trans ASME

Authors: Comini, G.; Saro, O.; Manzán, M.
Author full names: Comini, Gianni (7005313868); Saro, Onorio (7801581244); Manzán, Marco (6601986944)
Title: A physical approach to finite–element modeling of coupled conduction and convection
Source title: Numerical Heat Transfer, Part B: Fundamentals
Affiliations: Istituto di Fisica Tecnica e di Tecnologie Industriali, Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Comini, Gianni, Istituto di Fisica Tecnica e di Tecnologie Industriali, Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy; Saro, Onorio, Istituto di Fisica Tecnica e di Tecnologie Industriali, Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy; Manzán, Marco, Istituto di Fisica Tecnica e di Tecnologie Industriali, Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy
Abstract: Finite–element formulations for coupled conduction and convection problems are obtained by a direct approach based on energy balances, at both element and node levels. This way, clear physical interpretations are provided for all the essential steps of conventional finite–element procedures of the Galerkin type. In the examples, the finite–element formulation is validated first by comparison with the analytical solution of a typical benchmark problem. Then the capabilities of the finite–element method are demonstrated by the analysis of coupled conduction and convection problems of practical interest. © 1993 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Index Keywords: Finite element method; Heat conduction; Heat convection; Mathematical models; Coupled conduction and convection problems; Energy balances; Heat transfer
Abbreviated Source Title: Numer Heat Transfer Part B Fundam

Authors: Baratin, Laura; Crosilla, F.; Paronuzzi, Paolo
Author full names: Baratin, Laura May (6507783591); Crosilla, Fabio (6602452091); Paronuzzi, Paolo (57204594030)
Title: Image processing for determining joint parameters in difficult rock slope conditions
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Baratin, Laura May, Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy; Crosilla, Fabio, Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy; Paronuzzi, Paolo, Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy
Abstract: The survey of the geometrical parameters controlling the orientation and spatial frequency of the joints outcropping on rock walls is the starting procedure to assess the geomechanical behaviour of the rock mass. This is of particular importance in the case of civil and mining engineering applications, when high and steep rock scarps are to be monitored. Within the problem of monitoring geostructural discontinuities on a rock slope by photogrammetric facilities, image processing are becoming more and more important. In particular, Digital Terrain Model procedures implemented on analytical plotters, when enhanced with a certain software, allows the survey of the joint sets which characterize the local rock mass conditions. After a theoretical discussion of the method proposed, the paper reports the results obtained for a real rock slope. The photogrammetric acquired data are compared with direct measurements by using the conventional field survey methods. The good agreement between calculated and measured values shows that photogrammetric techniques are a powerful tool for rock slope characterization and monitoring.
Index Keywords: Image Processing - Image Analysis; Rock Mechanics - Computer Aided Analysis; Digital Terrain Model; Rock Slope Characterization; Photogrammetry
Editors: Gruen, A.; Baltsavias, E.
Publisher: Publ by Int Soc for Optical Engineering
Abbreviated Source Title: Proc SPIE Int Soc Opt Eng

Authors: De Angelis, A.
Author full names: De Angelis, Alessandro D. (7005924048)
Title: A class of N-dimensional probability density functions suitable for random generation
Affiliations: Institute of Physics, Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy
Authors with affiliations: De Angelis, Alessandro D., Institute of Physics, Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy
Abstract: The class of N-dimensional probability density functions such that the generation of a random vector can be reconducted through a linear transformation to the generation of N independent random numbers is described. Instances in physics when such functions can be used for parametrization in a Monte Carlo are discussed, in particular for random number generation according to the shape of an electromagnetic shower. © 1988.

Authors: Nobile, A.; Roberto, V.; Saitta, F.
Title: MFFT4: Four dimensional vectorized fast Fourier transforms
Affiliations: Scuola Internazionale Superiore di Studi Avanzati, Trieste, TS, Italy; Dipartimento di Matematica e Informatica, Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy

Abstract: In this paper we present the long write-up of MFFT4, an extension of a previous package (MFFT) to include four dimensional fast Fourier transform (FFT) subprograms in vector form. © 1988.

Authors: Cabras, G.; Roberto, V.; Salemi, G.

Title: UNIDFT: A package of optimized discrete fourier transforms
Affiliations: Institute of Physics, Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy; Dipartimento di Matematica e Informatica, Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy; Istituto di Scienze della Terra, Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Cabras, Giuseppe, Institute of Physics, Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy; Roberto, Vito, Dipartimento di Matematica e Informatica, Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy; Salemi, G., Istituto di Scienze della Terra, Università degli Studi di Udine, Udine, UD, Italy
Abstract: We present a package of FORTRAN 77 subprograms to compute the discrete Fourier transform of one-dimensional data sets. A large collection of specialized modules, assembled in a top-down scheme, guarantees high flexibility and efficiency. Comparative timings are given. © 1987.
